Dialogue.content: Hi, I'm Emily Zhang. I'm a psychology major.
Hello, Emily! It's great to meet you. How are you feeling today?
I'm feeling a bit disappointed. I had planned a get-together with some classmates, but one of my friends canceled last minute.
I'm sorry to hear that. It can be tough when plans fall through, especially when you're trying to connect with new people. How did that make you feel?
It made me question whether I can actually form friendships here. I feel a bit insecure about it.
That's completely normal. Starting fresh in a new environment can be challenging. What were you hoping to achieve with the get-together?
I just wanted to get to know my classmates better and build some friendships.

Building friendships takes time and effort, especially in a new setting. It's understandable to feel lonely now, but it doesn't define your ability to connect with others. Have you thought about reaching out to anyone else?
I haven't really. I guess I'm a little hesitant after this incident.
Hi again. I've been trying to reach out to classmates but it's been hard to connect. I feel more anxious.
It's good to see you again, Emily. It sounds like connecting with others hasn't been easy. What happened in your recent attempts?
I went to a group study session, but everyone seemed preoccupied and didn't engage with me. It felt isolating.
That sounds frustrating and can really heighten your feelings of isolation. Have you thought about what made it hard for you to connect?
I think it's partly my anxiety. I get worried that people won't want to talk to me.

That's a very common feeling. Remember, many people feel shy or anxious in new social situations. It doesn't mean they don't want to engage. How about trying to initiate a small conversation next time?
I'd like to try that, but it's intimidating.
I understand; it can be intimidating. Maybe starting with a compliment or a question about schoolwork could help ease you into it.
I attended a mental health workshop today. I shared my feelings, but I still feel disconnected.
It's great that you attended the workshop, Emily. It can be tough to open up about feelings. How did sharing your experience feel for you?
I thought it would help, but I still left feeling like nobody understands what I'm going through.
I can see how that would be disheartening. Feeling misunderstood can deepen feelings of loneliness. Have you given any thought to what you want to do moving forward?
Honestly, I'm starting to question if I should still pursue psychology. It's discouraging when I feel this way.

That's a significant concern. Remember, your passion for psychology doesn't disappear just because you're having a tough time connecting right now. Have you thought about seeking a professor's guidance?
I haven't really considered that. I just feel like I'm not doing well enough.
Hi, I've been reflecting on my situation. I think I want to talk to a professor about my feelings.
That's a positive step, Emily! It shows you're taking action to address how you've been feeling. What do you hope to gain from that conversation?
I'm hoping for some understanding and possibly to find out about more opportunities to connect with others who share my interests.
That sounds like a great plan. Also, exploring groups or clubs on campus could open new avenues for connection. Do any particular groups interest you?
Yes, I've been thinking about joining a psychology club or a volunteering group. It might help me meet new people.
Absolutely! Engaging in activities you enjoy can help you bond with like-minded individuals. How are you feeling about reaching out to your professor now?
I feel a bit hopeful, but I'm also nervous about opening up.
It's completely normal to feel nervous. Just remember, being open about your feelings takes courage and can lead you to supportive resources. I'm here for you if you need anything!
Thank you for your support! I really appreciate it. I'll keep you posted on how it goes.
You're welcome, Emily! Best of luck with your conversation. Take care!
